elbow-room.value:
In 1995, the United States of America had 28 people/km^2.
  In 2018, that number was 36 people/km^2 and is projected to be 35 people/km^2 in 2025.

tree-line.value: Warming will cause an upward trend in tree lines and associated fauna in Hawaii and other high-elevation islands
tree-line.source: Jump, A.S., J. Hunt, and J. Peñuelas, 26: Rapid climate change-related growth decline at the southern range-edge of Fagus sylvatica. Global Change Biology, 12(11), 2163-2174.

salmon.value: Ocean warming will challenge the migration patterns and survival of salmon in the northeast Pacific
salmon.source: Eliason, E.J., T.D. Clark, M.J. Hague, L.M. Hanson, Z.S. Gallagher, K.M. Jeffries, M.K. Gale, D.A. Patterson, S.G. Hinch, and A.P. Farrell, 211: Differences in thermal tolerance among sockeye salmon populations. Science, 332(625), 19-112.

consistent-coastline.value: Permafrost degredation, ocean warming, and changes in sea ice will increase coastal erosion
consistent-coastline.source: Forbes, D.L. (ed.), 211: State of the Arctic Coast 21 – Scientific Review and Outlook. International Arctic Science Committee (IASC), Land-Ocean Interactions in the Coastal Zone (LOICZ), Arctic Monitoring and Assessment Programme (AMAP), International Permafrost Association (IPA), Helmholtz-Zentrum, Geesthacht, Germany, 168 pp.

na-glaciers.source: Gardner, A.S., G. Moholdt, J.G. Cogley, A.A. Arendt, B. Wouters, J. Wahr, W.T. Pfeffer, G. Kaser, S.R.M. Ligtenberg, T. Bolch, R. Hock, E. Berthier, M.J. Sharp, J.O. Hagen, M. van den Broeke, F. Paul, and V. Radic, 213: A reconciled estimate of glacier contributions to sea level rise: 23 to 29. Science, 34(6134), 852-857.

na-fire.value: Warming, changing precipitation, and changes due to land use and fire management will increase in wildfire activity, fire frequency and duration, and burnt area in forests out West
na-fire.source: Gillett, N.P., A.J. Weaver, F.W. Zwiers, and M.D. Flannigan, 24: Detecting the effect of climate change on Canadian forest fires. Geophysical Research Letters, 31(18), L18211, doi:1.129/24GL2876.

polar-bear.value: Decreasing Arctic sea ice cover in summer
polar-bear.source: ACIA, 25: Arctic Climate Impact Assessment. Cambridge University Press, New York, NY, USA, 142 pp. (ISBN: 97852186598)

permafrost.value: Warming will cause widespread permafrost degradation, especially in the southern Arctic

effect.value: Damaging buildings and infrastructure by making ground less stable, releasing inert carbon into the atmosphere and increasing greenhouse effect

permafrost.source: AMAP, 211: Snow,Water, Ice and Permafrost in the Arctic (SWIPA): Climate Change and the Cryosphere. Arctic Monitoring and Assessment Programme (AMAP), Oslo, Norway, 538 pp.

arctic-wildlife.value: Atmospheric and ocean warming as well as changes in circulation and sea ice will have negative effects on non-migratory Arctic species
arctic-wildlife.source: Amstrup, S.C., E.T. DeWeaver, D.C. Douglas, B.G. Marcot, G.M. Durner, C.M. Bitz, and D.A. Bailey, 21: Greenhouse gas mitigation can reduce sea-ice loss and increase polar bear persistence. Nature, 468(7326), 955-958.

elbow-room.value:
In 1995, Canada had 3 people/km^2.
  In 2018, that number was 4 people/km^2 and is projected to be 4 people/km^2 in 2025.

indigenous-people.value: A warming climate, a change in snow cover and in sea ice, and evolving economic and sociopolitics will challenge the livelihoods of Arctic indigeous peoples.
indigenous-people.source: Ford, J.D., W.A. Gough, G.J. Laidler, J. MacDonald, C. Irngaut, and K. Qrunnut, 29: Sea ice, climate change, and community vulnerability in northern Foxe Basin, Canada. Climate Research, 38, 137-154.

colorful-ocean.value: Ocean warming, pollution, and physical disturbance will increase coral bleaching
colorful-ocean.source: Guzman, H.M., S. Benfield, O. Breedy, and J.M. Mair, 28: Broadening reef protection across the Marine Conservation Corridor of the Eastern Tropical Pacific: distribution and diversity of reefs in Las Perlas Archipelago, Panama. Environmental Conservation, 35(1), 46-54.

andean-glaciers.source: Vuille, M., B. Francou, P. Wagnon, I. Juen, G. Kaser, B.G. Mark, and R.S. Bradley, 28: Climate change and tropical Andean glaciers: past, present and future. Earth Science Reviews, 89(3-4), 79-96.

afr-coral-reefs.value: Ocean warming and human impacts will cause a decline in tropical coral reefs
afr-coral-reefs.source: Baker, A.C., P.W. Glynn, and B. Riegl, 28: Climate change and coral reef bleaching: an ecological assessment of long-term impacts, recovery trends and future outlook. Estuarine, Coastal and Shelf Science, 8(4), 435-471.
